section.title: Introduction
section.t: The proliferation of AI-generated content has created an urgent need for mechanisms that can attest to the human authorship process of digital works. Current approaches such as watermarking and AI-detection classifiers operate on the finished output and are increasingly unreliable as generative models improve.

This document specifies the Proof of Process (PoP) protocol, which takes a fundamentally different approach: rather than analyzing finished content, it captures tamper-evident evidence of the creation process itself. The framework builds on the IETF RATS architecture and defines roles, evidence formats, and verification procedures for process-based authorship attestation.

The key insight is that human authorship exhibits measurable behavioral characteristics — typing cadence, revision patterns, pause distributions, error-correction sequences — that are computationally expensive to fabricate in real time. By binding these behavioral observations to cryptographic time proofs, the framework creates evidence that is both tamper-evident and temporally authentic.
